title: RAMPS 1.4 case with mount for 80mm fan

description.text:
Case with a mount for an Arduino Mega 2560 and RAMPS 1.4 shield. Openings for wires, supports for zip ties, and a mount for an 80mm cooling fan. Also accomodates an LCD/controller  
edit: 02/12/2015 -- My initial upload had an older version of the sides, with the holes too far apart. I've also updated the top and bottom files to include an additional support at the edges for the bottom  
edit: 02/14/2015 -- Slight changes based on fitting the Arduino board to the front/back files, accomodating the power socket better, and I decided to make the holes for the screws after all, as drilling out the tiny holes is annoying. Motherboard mounting screws should work perfect.

Assembly is with 16 3mm screws and nuts, 10mm should be adequate in length, up to 15mm should be fine. Assembly should be reasonably obvious.  The holders are supposed to accomodate 5.5mm diameter nuts, however I'm using #4-32 screws since that's what I can buy cheaply at the hardware store, and those don't fit in the hex openings (But still work well.)  
The Arduino Mega 2560 should screw down to the bottom of the case. Some drilling may be required, depending on the screws used. Max 10mm screw length. I recommend that a coarse thread screw be used, as there is no nut provision.  
The fan should be able to be mounted to the inside of the case, but you will need screws longer than 10mm in order to reach, the fan will also probably have to be somewhat slim in order to leave clearance for the wiring inside the box. The current version, computer screws ought to work fine for this.  
Edit 02/18/2015:  
While assembling using the #4-40 screws, it occured to me that if I do not set the nuts in the top piece, it will be impossible to tighten the screws, so I used the following trick: I put a screw in through the side, and into a nut on the inside, then heated the nut with a soldering iron until it set into the plastic where the 3mm nut was supposed to sit. this worked well enough for me to get most of the nuts in place permanently. Don't do this without the screw in the nut, however, and don't remove the screw until the plastic has hardened again. not having the screw in place will probably block the hole (Happened once) and removing the screw too soon will get melted plastic in the way, making it difficult or impossible to thread in another screw. It will probably also foul the screw threads more or less permanently.

author: AwesomeA

title: Soap mold with flexifil on UP mini

description.text:
I have been experimenting with Flexifil from Formfutura to make soap molds. Normal extrusion temp should be around 210C so that means PLA setting but that doesnt work. The flexifil would only extrude on ABS setting. On that setting it would only extrude one time and that turned out to be beginners luck.
Also I could not remove the raft. The model and raft where as one. On PLA the filament would extrude only so much and than clog the extruder-inlet right after the PVC bearing block.
On the Inet of things I read that the gap between the extruder inlet and the little bearing should be zero or as minimal as possible.
The inlet on my extruder sits approx. 4.5mm below the black cooling block/nozzle assembly. So first I thought I need to fill that 4.5mm or redesign the filament guide. Turns out that the filament diameter is 2mm instead of 1.75mm. That is why on PLA clogs before it is soft enough for it to be extruded. ABS temp is high enough but well beyond extrusion temp. So I drilled out that extruder inlet tube with a 2.3mm drill. Now it will extrude at PLA setting and I can remove the raft. First of all I admit that a temp mod will also help in finding the right extrusion temp. Only a higher temp would ingrease the chance of the raft sticking to your model. Things to check before using the flexifil:
  • Check the filament diameter, if larger than 1.75 than try to drill out the inlet tube.
  • Is the filament spooled thight on the rol / This will ad more friction for the extruder motor to overcome.
    • Tip: The walls in my designs 1mm thick

comments.text: The soapmaker in me is surprised not to have thought of this before! Thank you!

title: Wax coating  your 3D print to make it water proof

description.text:
Easy Procedure to make your 3D print water proof -
stays food proof, if it was before!

You need
  • Candle Wax (Paraffine)
  • Heater gun
  • metallic bowl
  • old tooth brush
  • Bucket of Water( fire safety, just to be sure)
    • This is what you do
  • Make sure, your 3D print is dry and clean
  • Melt the wax with the heater gun, until it got good liquid
  • Use the Tooth brush to cover all surface of your 3D print with wax
  • You might need to grab it on the other side in order not to cover your fingers
    *Once all surface is covered ,your 3D print will look very unequally covered with Wax
  • Use the Heater gun on your 3D print very carefully in order not to burn it. Work from top to bottom and enable the extra wax to flow down off your 3D print. This is the dangerous step. Hot wax together with an catalysator might catch fire!
  • Heat up your 3D print again and use a paper towel to polish away the last wax arrears
    • Finally your print is still water proof. For me it appears, that it can even be used above wax's melting temperature.
    As Paraffine is used in medicine (fight blockage of digestion) its quite likely that paraffine does not harm your body Happy waxing !!! NO Warranty and NO Liability!!!!

description.text: Cap to (hopefully) keep your spindle from ruining your cardboard spool. I made a cardboard spool (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1550) a few weeks ago. I finally got tired enough of hand-feeding filament (and occasionally ruining a part as the z platform was pulled off the nuts by filament tension) to suspend my spool over the Makerbot.

0) Resize if necessary. My spindle is 8mm, so I use 10 mm for the spindle hole.
1) Print two.
2) Push one in on each side of your cardboard spool, with the sleeve & spikes going into the spool. If the spikes don't want to go in, pull it off & make guide holes with a nail.
3) Hot glue or otherwise adhere the cap to the cardboard if you don't think the friction will keep it. Print a suspension system: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6764

description.text: This lamp is a cheap knock-off of ... er, rather ... is a beautiful design inspired by the popular Voronoi Lamp (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:584714). All of the overhanging surfaces are at exactly 45 degrees, so it prints without supports, bridges or a lot of drama.

Update: I've added a solid version of the object (crinklelamp_solid.stl) which may be easier to slice. Printed in natural (clear) PLA with 0.2mm layers. It prints upside-down, from top to bottom. The wall thickness is specifically set for printing with exactly 2 line widths with a 0.4mm nozzle. Therefore, scaling this lamp may produce unpredictable slicing results. Originally, I sliced this with Slic3r 1.1.7, but it produced a tremendous number of unneeded traverse moves. The version shown was sliced with Simplify3D and printed without incident. Edit: According to UserUnrelated in his make (http://www.thingiverse.com/make:119553), the newest version of Slic3r (1.2.6) works fine on this model. He also scaled it to 50% and got a nice, fast printing, single wall print!

description.text: Compact box for 10W LED driver with ON/OFF switch.
name plate

This holds up to (12) 2.2LB Spools of material for my Afinia H480. I'm sure it will work with other printers as well. Everything was printed on the Afinia H480 except: (1) 3/16" x 3/4" cap screw
(1) 3/16" square weld nut
(1) 1/4" x 48" round steel
(1) 1/4" x 24" ice maker tubing
(1) 1" x 36" dowel rod (I used a broken broom handle)
Mount your spool over your Makerbot, so the Makerbot feeds itself.

1) Buy 4 dowels. Each should be about 12" (30cm) in length and about 5/16" (8mm) in diameter. (You can always edit the scad & regenerate if you already have dowels of differing length/diameter.)
2) Print two of each part.
3) Mount the clips top of your Makerbot.
4) Put dowels in the clip. The dowels should meet (or almost meet) about 10" above your bot.
5) Mount one joint on top of the dowels on one side, thread your spindle into it, thread the other joint on the other side of the spindle, then mount that joint on the other dowels. More detail about mounting the clips:
The 'U' part of each clip goes around the lip of the hole in the top of your bot. The overhang clips on the outside edge of the top of your bot. (I'll upload a pic of how they're mounted when I get home; currently I'm on the bus). If you need a spindle for a cardboard spool, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6763

We'll be updating the new edition to include rules for all of the Third Edition units, so if you have printed them (or want to), check in for updates and eventually all of those pieces' rules will be available. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

title: Samsung Galaxy Note Edge In Car CD Holder

description.text:
Hi Makers!  
Here is a holder for the Samsung Galaxy Note Edge. The thin section fits into the in car CD player slot. The phone sits in the cradle section with the screen facing outwards. Please note that this design does not take into account a phone using a custom case with the phone.

I recently became a proud owner of the Samsung Galaxy Note Edge and I really wanted a way to hold and use the phone's 'car mode features' whilst driving.  To that end I designed a holder in Solidworks which is supported by the in car CD drive.   I was directly inspired by some of the other designs on thingiverse for the Galaxy Note 2.  This is my first submission to Thingiverse so please be kind...  
I have  added some circular recesses to the base of the stand section to help secure the phone to the stand with neodymium magnets.  I bought some 3mm diameter 2mm depth neodymium magnets and glued then into the recesses.  In order to make the phone be attracted to the magnets I placed some ferrostrip (non magnetic iron impregnated tape) on the edge of the phone handset.  This secures the phone in the stand whilst going over speed bumps and rough terrain - the stand works without the magnets but I'm a belts and braces person.  The magnets and tape can be omitted if required.   
The design itself was printed on a Mendle 90 printer with 3mm black PLA using standard settings (195 degrees celcius at the extruder and 70 degrees celcuis on the heated bed).  
Enjoy!

description.text: A size 6 ring replica of a Birk's design. Channel set emeralds in gold.

The gems and ring should be properly placed relative to each other.  
I printed this on the flat size with the square holes down on a Replicator 2X.   
If you print it upright I'd be interested in seeing the results.

Here are some biased dice. I have yet to perfect the design and I am working on what to do with the corners of the dice and the underside. They should vary in how biased they are although currently they are all biased to land on 6. The percentage in the STL file name refers to how much of the internal space is filled. So "50" will be the most biased and "6.25" the least biased. I printed them with 100% infill and had no problem with bridging the gap when building the top layers. I printed them without any support. I will upload some more die (weighted to each number) once I have done some more analysis of the probabilities. There is still a lot to do so I welcome any advice and comments. Enjoy!

description.text:
A circular trinket/present box with the words "I LOVE YOU" embossed in the style of Morris/Goudy around the outside. There is a plain lid, or if you prefer, a lid with space for an insert of your loved one's initial printed separately and pressed in. As an alternative to the lettered lid insert, a customised message can be made from any image/drawing maybe a child's drawing or personal message. To make your own lid insert:
Make sure your image is square (the more pixels the better)
Drop it on http://3dp.rocks/lithophane
Set Max Size (MM) = 60, Thickness (MM) = 4, Border (MM) = 1.6, Thinnest layer (MM) = 0.6, Vectors per Pixel = 5, Base/Stand depth = 0, Form = "Flat, mirror Neg.". Then click on the image to download a customised STL insert for your lid.

The Base, Lid and Letter in the photo were all printed in at my lowest quality setting i.e. 100mm/s 0.32mm layer height, so anything you produce will look better :) I painted the one photographed with 2 coats of wood glue mixed with half a teaspoon of Brass Powder from eBay and then burnished it once it was dry. As described by Dizingof. http://www.3dizingof.com/3D-Printing/2015/01/metal-coating-3d-printed-plastic-designs-by-dizingof/ http://www.ebay.com/itm/MOULDCRAFT-Brass-Powder-Cold-Cast-Filler-275g-FIBREGLASS-POLYURETHANE-MOULDS-/251095878707 There is some debate as whether this is in the style of William Morris or is in-fact Goudy Initials by Frederic Goudy. I personally think it is closer to Goudy Initials. This work is based on images from the public domain. Either way, this font is still as lovely today as it was 100 years ago. It prints with no support. I'm sure it will print well in bronze fill, wood fill, etc. as well.

title: Sphere Dice
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: As noted by the title, this is a set of dice that are rounded like spheres. In the download I have included 8 stl files of the different dice in the set, a d20, d12, d10, percentile d10, d8, d6, d4, and d3, the OpenSCAD file that I wrote to make them, and a java program that I wrote to find the positions for the numbers. The dice in the model are decently small at 2cm in diameter, but with the OpenSCAD file, you should be able to make it of any size and make dice with other numbers of faces than listed here. (If you do choose to use the OpenSCAD file, to use the numbers you will need this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193) In regards to printability, I will say that these are pretty difficult to print for at least my printer considering the extremely small base and multiple overhangs, though I'm sure someone out there is able to print it just fine.

comments.text: I am going to try to print some of these, both with and without support. I will post pictures when I do it. I love these new age dice!

title: Quanum FPV goggles mount kit for Turnigy 9X

description.text: If you want to be able to have a monitor on your transmitter, but also being able to use it on your goggles and you happen to have a Quanum DYI goggles kit, then this is your lucky day! This kit allows you to move your Quanum FPV DIY monitor back and forth from your goggles to your transmitter with ease!. Instructions: 1) Cut the foam from the goggles as per pictures 2) Print all the required parts (test parts before gluing anything together, if necessary, use sandpaper to smooth surfaces to ensure proper sliding) 3) Sand off the back of the monitor such that the "lump" on the back is 4mm tall. (the reason for this step, is because tolerances on the print changes from printer to printer, and this is the best way to ensure a tight fit when using the transmitter bracket.) 4) assemble transmitter mount 5)Hot glue the monitor to the "screen box" (the "screen box part becomes strong once it is glue to the monitor, make sure you use enough glue to secure the monitor) 6) Hot glue the "goggles back plate full" to the foam goggles (after installing all other required components, like lense holder) 7) Assemble the transmitter mount and install 8) Assemble the monitor holder to the transmitter mount by using some bolts, washers and wing nuts. 9)Enjoy! Credits for the stand holder for the Turnigy 9X goes to its maker http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:247039

Instructions:  
1) Cut the foam from the goggles as per pictures  
2) Print all the required parts (test parts before gluing anything together, if necessary, use sandpaper to smooth surfaces to ensure proper sliding)  
3) Sand off the back of the monitor such that the "lump" on the back is 4mm tall. (the reason for this step, is because tolerances on the print changes from printer to printer, and this is the best way to ensure a tight fit when using the transmitter bracket.)  
4) assemble transmitter mount  
5)Hot glue the monitor to the "screen box" (the "screen box part becomes strong once it is glue to the monitor, make sure you use enough glue to secure the monitor)  
6) Hot glue the "goggles back plate full" to the foam goggles (after installing all other required components, like lense holder)  
7)  Assemble the transmitter mount and install  
8) Assemble the monitor holder to the transmitter mount by using some bolts, washers and wing nuts.   
9)Enjoy!

They warped? I'm assuming you are printing in ABS. If I can give advise on how I print my parts with ABS.
I never use the fans, I made a simple heat chamber to avoid any air flow on the parts during prints. With the heated bed it keeps the part at the correct temperature avoiding any warp. If I print very fine little pieces I have aquarium air pump with a hose that comes to blow precisely at the edge of the extruder.

comments.text: Do you think translucent blue filament would be just as good? Im currently printing my brain and I'm hoping translucent blue would allow enough light to come through and emphasize all my gyri & sulci. Let me know, thanks!
comments.author: Netters

comments.text: I'll be honest, mine looks much better in the photos :) I had used translucent white PLA and the light doesn't like to shine all the way through. I found that when I printed the second half at a slightly higher temperature, the Pla became much more clear. If the blue is fairly transparent, you may be able to use some bright white leds to make it glow blue. I would also suggest printing at as low infill as you think your printer can handle. That way the brain will be less dense internally and hopefully allow more light to spread across. Post some pictures when you get it finished!

description.text: This is a remix of Lawsy's Filament Guide http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:85707. I used the ideas there and redid it in Fusion 360. The connections to the Z table rods are not as tight, and it's held in place by magnets rather than clipping in. I also rounded the front edges slightly and made the rear hole 6mm. This allows me to use silicone to glue a length of PTFE tubing in place. It helps protect the filament more, and it extends far enough to the back that the filament spool no longer seems to spontaneously unwind.

remixed_from.title: Wow, Letters A-Z & Numbers 0-9 in Tahoma-like extruded font.

description.text: Klingon pIqaD Alphabet

This is an 5mm extruded Klingon pIqaD alphabet with letters about 1" tall.  If you have to ask "why?", you're looking at the wrong thing.  
I just typed out the alphabet and then saved each letter, so the positions are probably bizzare, but the relative height & spacing should be correct.  One way to use them is to mash them into whatever else you're making.  
Attached is also my font, which this came from, encoded according th the "ConScript" encoding for pIqaD.  Using the font in your 3D modeling program may be easier than using these extrusions.  
Non-Klingon Speakers:

One way for non-Klingons to use this font would be to install the font, go to the Bing Translater, http://www.bing.com/translator/?from=en&to=tlh-Qaak, and translate whatever. The copy the results to your 3D modeling program, picking the pIqaD font to render them in. Let me know if you use this for anything. This thing lives at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:676876 Trivia:
The underlying font is also the same font used for pIqaD by Bing Translator. http://www.bing.com/translator/? from=en&to=tlh-Qaak&text=Hello%20Earth,%20I%20made%20the%20font For Fun:

If you want to support my 3D projects, check out and share my completely unrelated, wrong canon, yet still cool, Working Lego R2-D2 YouTube channel at http://www.youtube.com/MyL3G0 - I make a few pennies off the ads.

title: Sony HDR AS20, AS15, etc. No-Gimbal Mount for DJI Phantom 2

description.text:
I have progressed beyond this to working on a gimbaled version, but thought someone might want to use these files which I used on my testbed Phantom a couple of months ago.
I will post the sequel with a controller when I get it finished.
You will need to use 2 M3 screws and nuts to attach the bracket to the plate and an M5 (or M4 with a sleeve) screw and nut for mounting the camera clamp to the bracket. You will also need 4 anti-jello rubber mounts: 7mm x 21mm. Not the tiny DJI type.
Print 2 plates. These plates have all the holes for this design and will be the same for the controller and gimbal version.
You will also need 4 M3 screws to attach the upper plate to the body of the Phantom.
That white thing is a lens cap available elsewhere here on Thingyverse. AN ALTERNATE PLATE DESIGN CAN BE FOUND HERE:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:677486

The MakerBot Gen4 Interface board is a DIY addition to your MakerBot that will allow you to interact directly with the machine. It has multiple buttons, multiple LEDs, and a 16x4 character LCD screen to provide feedback directly to you. Using this board, it is possible to run your MakerBot completely independently with no computer attached. You can set and read the temperature, view the progress of a build, and even start a new build from a file stored on the SD card. Of course you can also hack the firmware to make it anything else you might want as well.
This kit is DIY, and soldering is required. All the components are through-hole so it is a great kit for beginners.
You can buy it from the MakerBot Store at: http://store.makerbot.com/makerbot-interface-board-kit-v1-1.html Full documentation at: http://wiki.makerbot.com/mib1

title: BigCooter 7" LCD Touch Display Monitor case

description.text:
UPDATED 28-JUNE-2015: added mounting system for Picatinny rail 20mm. Picatinny rail design uploaded here can be attached to openbeam 1515 extrusions, or anywhere the 4 mounting holes can be used. Note, there are numerous holes on the back of the main housing which can be tapped to M3 for adding your own custom mounting solutions and/or accessories. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fLj95JFuSHw More instructions, and links to purchase LCD display panel / electronics for under $50 at http://BigCooter.com/?p=1416 Case designed for low cost electronics:

7" AT070TN92 LCD (16:9 ratio)
HDMI+VGA+2AV LCD control board, LVDS, chipset RTD2660H
Touch Screen Panel (eGalax)

FDM print these parts flat side down, NO support material, 0.2mm layer height, 0.4mm nozzle and 15% infill. Part photos were made with low cost PLA materials. Circuit board mount screws are M3 x 6mm button head, case end screws are M3 x 12mm button head. Drill threaded holes to 2.5mm, tap or self thread with M3 ... M3 screw clearance holes can be drilled to anything between 3.0 and 3.3mm diameter. 4/11/2015: Added optional bezel spacer stl file, for use when not using touch screen digitizer panel (note: original LCD screen and touch digitizer screen bonded stack was 165.2 x 100.2 x 5.3mm). Also, reduced stiffness of switch plate buttons, should be easier to depress now. This LCD panel seems to work well with OctoPi (OctoPrint) on a Raspberry PI 2, shown here running on Chromium browser in Kiosk mode. I had planned to use the touch panel with this Raspberry Pi 2, but the eGalax touch panel is NOT supported by the Raspbian RPi operating system, kernel / drivers must be rebuilt for this, I'm not a software nut, so I gave up trying ... anyone else up for the challenge of building a good Raspbian eGalax OctoPi image, please reply below!!!! Until someone figures out an easy way to get the eGalax touch panel working, I suggest not including it .. the LCD kits are about $10 less without it ... I have included an optional spacer STL model for taking the place of the touch screen digitizer glass. I have found this display unit very useful for setting up and debugging Raspberry Pies, well worth the ~$40 it will cost to build without touch panel. Note there are only cutouts in the lower housing for the HDMI, Power, and touch panel USB cord ... additional cutouts for VGA, audio, etc.. can be added by someone wanted to do a remix. This is meant to be a multi-purpose design, that is why I placed many optional mounting holes on the backside of the lower housing ... drill to 2.5mm and tap or self thread M3 screws into those holes to attach your mounting bracket designs.
intentionally left blank, refer to Description Area.

author: BigCooter

description.text:
After doing the XL upgrade, my X axis started slipping regularly on large prints.  It was frustrating to reset the x belt only to have it slip off again.  I noticed that the belt swam as it traveled the full xl length.  
That's when I thought up Guide Washers.  If only the front washer on the guide bearings was a bit bigger.  That would keep the belt from slipping off.  
I hope Printbot sees this and incorporates this modification in the Simple.  
This one is dedicated to my partner and friend, Tux Kitty.  Believe it or not, this cat helps me with every crazy project I do.

Printed on a PrintrBot Simple with Factory Settings.  
Y Axis:  Simply loosen and remove tensioner.  Replace most outward washer with guide washer.  Try to get the washer under the gear motor lip for additional support.  
X Axis: You must remove both sides of the body to free the table.  Clip the anchored X belt retaining zip tie.  I had to remove one of the two inner washers to get this one to fit under the gear motor lip.  Feed the belt through and around by manually cranking the gear.  Reattach.  Reassemble.

I was just printing and two of my parts didn't work out. I ended up getting some strings on the good part and because I can't get my fingers let alone my hand in there, I had to make a new longer scraper to help me with this if it comes up again. I also can't get my hand through the top as the cb is in a shelf so this will hopefully help.

This is a simple extrusion for a scraper. Nothing special, I just needed a longer one this time.  As you can see I like to keep my stuff simple or as simple as I can.  
It's 200mm long, 4 mm thick and 20 mm wide. I will be printing it next once my current print gets done.  
I noticed that printing these on medium or higher is best. Also print this on it's side instead of flat as the layers will be smooth. If you print it flat you will have steps instead of the nice smooth angle. Use a small brim to keep it in place and you should be good. I just tried printing it flat and I get steps. I printed the small one on its side and it's smooth on that angled side.
I designed this for the printer in our office, it was recently moved to an open cubicle and so it needed a safety cover to keep curious fingers at bay.

This designed to cover the UP Plus printer.  
Print all corner, hinge and door stop parts, cut 6mm thick clear plastic of your choice and drill mounting holes, assemble with 52 M3 x 0.5 x 12 SBHCS and 4 M3 X 15 DOWEL PINS.  
I was asked to share the models so I've included STEP AP203 versions of the assembly and printed parts.

description.text:
TEC é uma linha de peças para criação de brinquedos. As peças podem ser encaixadas livremente umas nas outras, além da possiblidade de serem encaixadas em outros objetos, como embalagens recicláveis. A idéia é incentivar a reutilização de objetos para a fabricação de novos brinquedos. Aproveite!  
TEC is a line of pieces for toys creation. The pieces can be freely joined, beyond the possibility of joining it with other products, like recyclable packages. The idea is to encourage the reuse of objects to fabricate new toys. Hope you enjoy it!
